point_help: Attribute in Basic cluster
name: Year

point_help: Select whether the inverter operates independently of the grid, or is connected to the grid. If off-grid, you should also ignore grid-loss warnings.
name: Mode
friendly_meanings: Off-Grid.  There is no available power grid,Grid-Tied. Grid power is available.

point_help: Select how solar power is prioritized. Self-consumption: PV powers the home first, then charges the battery, and exports last (if allowed). Export first: PV powers the home, then exports to grid, and charges the battery last. Backup power: PV charges the battery first to build reserve, then powers the home, and exports last (if allowed). If a battery schedule is running (PV Charge Only, Discharge Only, or Grid Charge), the inverter will follow that schedule during those times instead of this operating mode. When the scheduled period ends, the inverter will return to the selected operating mode.
name: Mode
meanings: Self used mode,Feed-in priority mode,Back-up mode

point_help: When enabled, the inverter will not treat the absence of grid power as an alarm. Use this mode for permanently off-grid systems where grid connection is unavailable.
name: Grid-Loss Behavior

point_help: Put the inverter into standby mode to stop operation or make configuration changes. While in standby, the inverter will not generate PV power or charge/discharge the battery. If grid power is available, it be used to supply the loads. If the grid is unavailable, the building will not have power.
name: State

point_help:
Turns the inverter output on or off.

• **Standby:** AC output is disabled, but control circuits remain powered.
• **Power On:** Enables AC output and normal inverter operation.
name: Power State

point_help: Shows whether power output limiting is currently active. When not limited, the inverter can deliver its full available power (subject only to natural hardware limits). When limited, an external or configured cap is applied to restrict inverter output to the specified Power Limit.
name: Mode
friendly_meanings: Not limited - full output,Limit output power

point_help: The inverter's present active-power output limit as a percentage of its rated capacity. If power limiting is active, the inverter will limit its output power to this percentage of its rated capacity.
name: Power Limit (%)

point_help: Allows the inverter to sell/export power back to the utility grid. Enable this only if local regulations and interconnect agreements permit grid export.
Sets the maximum power the inverter is allowed to sell/export to the grid. Use this to meet utility export limits or site commissioning requirements.
name: Power (kW)

point_help: Keeps power export at or near zero by adjusting inverter output in real time. When enabled, the inverter supplies only local (on-site) loads and will not send power back to the grid. This mode is required when grid export is not allowed. Ensure the CTs are installed on the grid connection point and  not on the inverter's load side, so the inverter can correctly detect and prevent export.
name: Fast Zero Export

point_help: Attribute in ACCharge cluster
name: SOC

point_help: The Unit ID (also known as the unit ID, slave ID, or node ID) for this inverter. The primary inverter should use address 1, and any secondary inverters should use 2 or higher. This sets the modbus address that inverters use to communicate with each other. Each inverter that communicates on the same Modbus communication line must have a unique address, but addresses do not need to be globally unique across separate, unconnected systems.
name: Address

point_help:
Defines how this inverter participates in a multi-inverter or multi-phase system.

• No Parallel: Single inverter system.
• Single-phase Parallel (Master / Secondary): Multiple inverters on one phase.
• Three-phase Parallel (Master): Multiple inverters forming R/S/T phases.
name: Parallel Role / Topology
meanings: no parallel (single one),Single-phase parallel(Master),Secondary,Three phase parallel(Master)
friendly_meanings: No Parallel (Single Inverter),Single-Phase Parallel (Master),Single-Phase Parallel (Secondary),Three-Phase Parallel (Master)

point_help: Selects which output phase this inverter is responsible for in a three-phase system. R, S, and T correspond to L1, L2, and L3.
name: Phase

point_help: Clears the detected phases for this inverter.
name: Phase

point_help: Attribute in Parallel cluster
name: Phase

point_help: Allows inverters in a parallel group to use a common battery bank instead of keeping batteries isolated per inverter.
name: Installation Method
friendly_meanings: Inverters have Separate Batteries,Inverters Share a Common Battery Bank

point_help: Total number of inverters detected in this parallel system.
name: Num

point_help: Reports whether this inverter is acting as Primary (sometimes called the Master) or Secondary in the current parallel configuration.
name: Role

point_help: Reports which phase (R / S / T) this inverter is currently serving in the parallel system.
name: Phase

point_help: Select the current transformer (CT) ratio used for metering electric current on the grid port connection. This must match the CT hardware rating so that current and power readings are accurate.
name: CT Ratio

point_help: Sets the CT installation direction. You may choose to reverse this if your inverter is reading import when power is actually flowing out to the grid (export) or vice versa.
name: Direction

point_help: Specifies the chemistry or general type of connected battery. Choose **No Battery** for standalone PV or grid-tie operation, **Lead-acid** for flooded or AGM batteries, or **Lithium-ion** for managed BMS packs.
name: Type

point_help: Selects the manufacturer profile for the connected battery. This may pre-configure recommended voltage and SOC limits for optimal operation.
name: Brand

point_help: Sets the voltage used during the absorb (bulk-to-float transition) phase. Increasing this value raises the upper charge threshold for lead-acid batteries.
name: Voltage (Vdc)

point_help: Defines the voltage maintained once the battery is fully charged. This helps prevent overcharging while keeping the battery topped off.
name: Voltage (Vdc)

point_help: Voltage threshold where the inverter begins reducing charge or discharge current to protect the battery as it approaches full or low state.
name: Voltage (Vdc)

point_help:
Determines how the inverter regulates both charging and discharging.

SOC: Uses battery state of charge thresholds to start and stop charge/discharge.

Volt: Uses DC voltage limits instead.
name: Charge Control

point_help: Sets the maximum state of charge (SOC) the battery will be charged to. Once the battery reaches this level, charging stops to prevent overcharging and extend lifespan.
name: SOC (%)

point_help: Sets the maximum charging and discharging current allowed for the connected inverter. Choose the preset that matches your inverter model to automatically apply the correct limits.
name: Max Charge Preset

point_help: Sets the minimum state of charge (SOC) the battery will discharge to while grid power is available. Below this level, the inverter will stop discharging and switch to grid power to protect battery capacity.
name: SOC (%)
description: Recommended: between 21-90%.  Must be higher than the Off-Grid Battery Cutoff SOC.

point_help: Sets the minimum state of charge (SOC) the battery will discharge to when operating off-grid. Once the battery reaches this level, the inverter stops discharging to prevent deep discharge and maintain battery health.
name: SOC (%)
description: Recommended: between 20-89%.  Must be lower than the On-Grid Battery Cutoff SOC.

point_help: Enables or disables battery-backup operation. When enabled, the inverter reserves part of the battery capacity to power critical loads during a grid outage.

While Battery Backup Mode is enabled, the battery will stop discharging once it reaches this level. When Backup Mode is disabled, normal operation applies and discharge will continue down to the On-Grid or Off-Grid Battery Cutoff SOC.
name: SOC (%)

point_help: This is a special scheduling mode designed for certain time-of-use (TOU) utility rates or other custom situations. In most circumstances, we recomment allowing your system to  manage charging and discharging automatically without setting a schedule.  You don't need to set a schedule unless you have a specific reason to charge or discharge at exact times.
name: Scheduling
friendly_meanings: Disable Scheduling,Enable the 'PV Charge Only' and 'Discharge Only' scheduling modes

point_title: Max Battery Charge Power During 'PV Charge Only' Periods
point_help: Sets the maximum charging power during scheduled Time-of-Use (TOU) charge periods in kW. Set this limit to control the power level at which the battery will charge from the grid during PV charge only periods
name: Power (kW)
description: Should not exceed the inverter's rated power

point_title: Schedule Window 1 for PV Charge Only
point_help: During these times your battery will charge from solar power and not discharge to power your home unless there is a grid power outage
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_title: Schedule Window 2 for PV Charge Only
point_help: During these times your battery will charge from solar power and not discharge to power your home unless there is a grid power outage
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_title: Schedule Window 3 for PV Charge Only
point_help: During these times your battery will charge from solar power and not discharge to power your home unless there is a grid power outage
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_title: Max Inverter Output Power During 'Discharge Only' Periods
point_help: Sets the maximum discharging power during scheduled Time-of-Use (TOU) discharge periods in kW. Limit this to control how much battery power is exported to loads or grid during those windows.
name: Power (kW)
description: Should not exceed the inverter's rated power

point_help: Sets the minimum state of charge (SOC) that the battery will discharge to during 'Discharge Only' operation. Once this level is reached, discharging stops to preserve reserve capacity for later use or backup.
name: SOC (%)

point_help: During these times, your battery will discharge at a steady rate and not charge from solar power.  Solar power will be used in your home and sold to the grid as allowed
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_help: During these times, your battery will discharge at a steady rate and not charge from solar power.  Solar power will be used in your home and sold to the grid as allowed
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_help: During these times, your battery will discharge at a steady rate and not charge from solar power.  Solar power will be used in your home and sold to the grid as allowed
name: Start Hour (0-23)

point_help: Enables the battery to charge from the utility grid.
name: Grid Charge
friendly_meanings: Do not charge the battery from grid power,Allowed

point_help: Sets the maximum power the inverter will draw from the grid for charging. This cap applies when Grid Charge is enabled (and within any configured time windows).
name: Max Grid Charge Power (W)

point_help: Defines when grid charging starts and stops based on battery state of charge (SOC). Charging starts when SOC falls below Start SOC and stops when it reaches Stop SOC.
name: Start SOC (%)

point_help: Select whether grid charging follows a time schedule or SOC/voltage thresholds.
name: Control Type

point_help: During these times, your battery will continue to charge from solar power normally, but will also use additional power from the grid to charge the battery.
name: Window 1 Start Hour

point_help: This setting changes the conditions under which the inverter will connect or disconnect from the utility grid. Different areas have different rules about when this equipment is allowed to disconnect and when it must ride through. Choose the code required by the local utility or AHJ.
name: Code

point_help: Choose wiring configuration of the site.  This helps configure the system to match the power service at the site.  Note the voltage you enter here must match the EPS Voltage.
name: Service Type

point_help: Sets the nominal grid frequency for the installation. Use 60 Hz for North America and most split-phase installs; use 50 Hz for regions that operate at 230 V single-phase.
name: Frequency (Hz)

point_help: Voltage trip window. If grid voltage rises above or falls below these thresholds for longer than the threshold time allows, the inverter will disconnect from the grid.
name: Upper Limit (Vac)

point_help: Voltage trip window. If grid voltage rises above or falls below these thresholds for longer than the threshold time allows, the inverter will disconnect from the grid.
name: Upper Limit (Vac)

point_help: Voltage trip window. If grid voltage rises above or falls below these thresholds for longer than the threshold time allows, the inverter will disconnect from the grid.
name: Upper Limit (Vac)

point_help: Sets the upper and lower grid frequency thresholds. If grid frequency goes outside this range, the inverter will disconnect from the grid to protect the system and comply with grid safety standards.
name: Upper Limit (Hz)

point_help: Sets the upper and lower grid frequency thresholds. If grid frequency goes outside this range, the inverter will disconnect from the grid to protect the system and comply with grid safety standards.
name: Upper Limit (Hz)

point_help: Sets the upper and lower grid frequency thresholds. If grid frequency goes outside this range, the inverter will disconnect from the grid to protect the system and comply with grid safety standards.
name: Upper Limit (Hz)

point_help: Defines how long the grid voltage must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 1) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: Low Voltage Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Defines how long the grid voltage must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 2) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: Low Voltage Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Defines how long the grid voltage must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 3) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: Low Voltage Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Defines how long the grid frequency must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 1) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: High Frequency Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Defines how long the grid frequency must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 2) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: High Frequency Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Defines how long the grid frequency must remain below the lower limit or above the upper limit (Stage 3) before the inverter disconnects from the grid.
name: High Frequency Trip Delay (ms)

point_help: Shows whether the inverter is permitted to operate in grid-connected mode.
name: Permit Status

point_help: How quickly inverter output is allowed to increase.
name: Ramp Rate (%/sec)

point_help: Voltage window within which grid connection is permitted. Outside this range the inverter will not connect or will disconnect.
name: Lower Limit (Vac)

point_help: Frequency window within which grid connection is permitted. Outside this range the inverter will not connect or will disconnect.
name: Lower Limit (Hz)

point_help: Delays applied before initial grid connection and after a grid disturbance clears (reconnection). These timers help meet interconnection standards.  The connection delay is how long the inverter will wait after first being powered on.  Reconnection delay is how long the inverter will wait after a grid disturbance or outage clears.
name: Connection Delay (s)

point_help: Shows whether constant power-factor control is active.
name: Status
friendly_meanings: Inactive — No PF control,Active — Constant PF

point_help: The target power factor and excitation. Under-excited = lagging (absorbing vars); Over-excited = leading (supplying vars).
name: Excitation

point_help: Shows whether constant reactive-power control is active.
name: Excitation
Status
friendly_meanings: Inactive - no reactive power control,Active - reactive power control

point_help: Displays the reactive-power target as a percentage of rated power (vars). Excitation determines whether vars are supplied (leading) or absorbed (lagging).
name: Reactive Power (%)

point_help: Shows whether Volt-VAR (voltage-reactive power) control is active. This value is read-only and reflects the current configuration or utility command.
name: Mode
friendly_meanings: Inactive - no Volt-VAR control,Active - Volt-VAR control

point_help: Indicates whether the inverter autonomously adjusts its reference voltage (Vref).
name: Autonomous Adjustment

point_help: Voltage reference used for Volt-VAR calculations.
name: Vref

point_help: Time constant applied when adjusting Vref.
name: Time Constant

point_help: Voltage points (V1-V4) that define the Volt-VAR curve breakpoints.
name: V1 (Voltage Point 1)

point_help: Reactive power at voltage point V1 on the Volt-VAR curve.
name: Q1 (Reactive Setpoint 1)

point_help: Reactive power at voltage point V2 on the Volt-VAR curve.
name: Q2 (Reactive Setpoint 2)

point_help: Reactive power at voltage point V3 on the Volt-VAR curve.
name: Q3 (Reactive Setpoint 3)

point_help: Reactive power at voltage point V4 on the Volt-VAR curve.
name: Q4 (Reactive Setpoint 4)

point_help: Response time used for open-loop Volt-VAR changes.
name: Response Time

point_help: Shows whether Active/Reactive Power (P-Q) control mode is enabled.
name: Mode
friendly_meanings: Inactive - no P-Q control,Active - P-Q control

point_help: Breakpoint setpoints for the Active/Reactive Power (P-Q) characteristic.
name: P1 Setpoint

point_help: Shows whether Volt-Watt (voltage-active power) control is enabled.
name: Mode
friendly_meanings: Inactive - no Volt-Watt control,Active - Volt-Watt control

point_help: Voltage points that define the Volt-Watt curve.
name: V1 (Voltage Point 1)

point_help: Power setpoint at voltage breakpoint V2 on the Volt-Watt curve.
name: P2 Setpoint

point_help: Response time used for open-loop Volt-Watt changes.
name: Response Time

point_help: Indicates whether frequency-power (Freq-Watt) control is currently enabled.
name: Mode

point_help: Response time applied to open-loop frequency-power adjustments.
name: Response Time

point_help: Over Frequency Droop dbOF — Deadband around nominal frequency before active power reduction begins.
name: Deadband (Hz)

point_help: Over Frequency Droop kOF — Slope (gain k) of active power reduction versus frequency rise above nominal.
name: Gain k (slope)

point_help: Under Frequency Droop dbUF — Deadband around nominal frequency before active power increase/response begins.
name: Deadband (Hz)

point_help: Under Frequency Droop kUF — Slope (gain k) of active power response versus frequency drop below nominal.
name: Gain k (slope)

point_help: Controls whether the inverter provides AC output when operating without the utility grid. Disable to prevent output in off-grid mode.
Selects the AC output voltage when operating in backup (EPS) mode. Match this to your local service voltage for proper compatibility with connected loads.
name: Voltage (Vac)

point_help: If using a generator, select which port it's connected to — either the GEN port or the Grid Input port (sometimes called microgrid mode). If no generator is installed, leave this setting on GEN port.
name: Generator connected to
friendly_meanings: GEN port (also select if not using generator).,Grid port (aka microgrid mode)

point_help: Sets the maximum DC current the inverter will send to the battery when charging from the generator.
name: Charge Current (Adc)

point_help: Specify the generator's continuous rated output power.
name: Rated Power (kW)

point_help: Sets the time the generator continues running after charging stops to allow for safe cooling.
name: Cool-Down Time (min)

point_help: Configures the battery state of charge thresholds for automatic generator control. The generator will start when battery SOC drops to StartSOC and stop when it reaches StopSOC.
name: Start SOC (%)
description: Generator starts when battery drops to this level

name: Stop SOC (%)
description: Generator stops when battery charges to this level

point_help: Indicates the current state of the generator control contactor.
name: Contactor State

point_help: Start the generator to charge the battery.
Enables dynamic adjustment of generator charging power for faster battery recovery when needed.
Enable this option when connecting a grid-tied solar inverter (AC Coupled PV) to the system. Disable when no AC Coupled PV is present.
name: AC Coupled PV Mode

point_help: Defines the battery state-of-charge thresholds that control when the inverter allows AC Coupled PV charging to start and stop.
name: Start SOC (%)
description: AC Coupled PV begins charging when SOC drops to this level

name: Stop SOC (%)
description: AC Coupled PV stops charging when SOC reaches this level

point_help: Powers non-essential loads only when excess solar or battery energy is available. Enable this to automatically use surplus energy for optional circuits.
Determines Smart Load behavior while the system is connected to the grid. When enabled, the Smart Load remains powered even if normal control conditions are not met. (AKA: **On-Grid Always On**.)
name: On-Grid Always-On Mode
friendly_meanings: Follow normal rules,Always On When Grid Present

point_help: Defines when the Smart Load turns on. The Smart Load port is energized once PV power exceeds this threshold **and** the battery SOC is above the start limit.
name: PV Power Above (W)

point_help: Defines the battery state-of-charge limits that control the Smart Load. The Smart Load turns on when SOC rises above the start limit **and** PV power exceeds the start power limit.  Smart load turns off when SOC falls below the stop limit.
name: Start When Battery SOC Is Above (%)
Stop When Battery SOC Is Below (%)
